column4: Thanks as well, I didn't understand any of that, but it might have saved me some trouble
Is "gconf-editor" that?
Yes, all settings in gconf-editor are stored in $HOME/.gconf and many gnome apps use these settings
If they were to become owned by root, other user apps would no longer be able to write and save settings
Are you telling me not to listen to oCean?
So far as running gconf-editor as root (with gksudo), yes
But as just "gconf-editor", it is fine?
yes
You can also re-own all files in .gconf by running as your normal user: sudo chown -R $USER $HOME/.gconf
I don't know what you mean by "re-own"
It will only not ask for password if you have entered it recently
Actually, that whole line seemed like gibberish to me

ie. in case you ran gconf-editor with escalated permissions (with sudo, gksu or gksudo) and changed any setting (it will write the file as root and subsequently own it to root) then you can recursively (that is what -R means here) re-own the permissions to your normal user with the aforementioned command
Y
Sorry, you will have to dumb that down alot if you want me to understand that
Lets just assume everything is ok :)
So no changes?
Should be fine, I was just making a point
Sorry I couldn't understand it for you, perhaps I will shove it into a tomeboy note and hope to understand it in the future
The underlying message is, never run anything as root unless you know why you need to
Even there, I don't know what it means to run things as root (except for real basic principle) or even if I have run X command as root or not
Running as root means you used gksu, gksudo or sudo, or if you are logged in as root at your terminal, the last character will be a #. For user, the last char for your prompt is $
Administrator and user are the same to me, being the only person who uses this PC
That is the mistake most people make. They are entirely not the same thing
